skill.name: pylabrobot
skill.description: Vendor-agnostic lab automation framework. Use when controlling multiple equipment types (Hamilton, Tecan, Opentrons, plate readers, pumps) or needing unified programming across different vendors. Best for complex workflows, multi-vendor setups, simulation. For Opentrons-only protocols with official API, opentrons-integration may be simpler.
skill.summary: Control liquid handling robots and lab equipment with unified Python interface
skill.author: K-Dense Inc.

security_audit.summary: PyLabRobot is a legitimate open-source laboratory automation framework. All 416 static findings are FALSE POSITIVES caused by the scanner misidentifying markdown documentation syntax as executable code. The backticks flagged as 'Ruby/shell backtick execution' are markdown code formatting, not shell commands. URLs and IP addresses are legitimate documentation references for lab equipment connectivity. The skill poses no security risk.

static_findings_evaluation.finding: [MEDIUM] external_commands: Ruby/shell backtick execution at references/analytical-equipment.md:26
static_findings_evaluation.reasoning: The backtick character in markdown is syntax for inline code formatting (e.g., `CLARIOstarBackend()`). This is documentation, not actual command execution. No shell or Ruby commands are present.

static_findings_evaluation.finding: [MEDIUM] external_commands: Ruby/shell backtick execution at references/hardware-backends.md:5
static_findings_evaluation.reasoning: Backticks in markdown format Python code examples like `LiquidHandler`. This is standard documentation syntax, not shell command execution.

static_findings_evaluation.finding: [MEDIUM] external_commands: Ruby/shell backtick execution at references/liquid-handling.md:5
static_findings_evaluation.reasoning: Inline code formatting with backticks for Python class names like `LiquidHandler`. Documentation only, no actual command execution.

static_findings_evaluation.finding: [MEDIUM] external_commands: Ruby/shell backtick execution at references/material-handling.md:15
static_findings_evaluation.reasoning: Markdown code formatting for Python imports and class names. No shell commands present.

static_findings_evaluation.finding: [MEDIUM] external_commands: Ruby/shell backtick execution at references/resources.md:17
static_findings_evaluation.reasoning: Documentation examples using backtick syntax for inline code. Standard markdown, not command execution.

static_findings_evaluation.finding: [MEDIUM] external_commands: Ruby/shell backtick execution at references/visualization.md:22
static_findings_evaluation.reasoning: Python code examples in markdown documentation. Backticks indicate code formatting only.

static_findings_evaluation.finding: [MEDIUM] external_commands: Ruby/shell backtick execution at SKILL.md:32
static_findings_evaluation.reasoning: File references like `references/liquid-handling.md` in documentation. Not actual command execution.
Documentation URL to official PyLabRobot docs (docs.pylabrobot.org). Legitimate reference link, not sensitive endpoint.

static_findings_evaluation.finding: [MEDIUM] network: Hardcoded IP address at references/hardware-backends.md:121
static_findings_evaluation.reasoning: Example IP address `192.168.1.100` for Opentrons OT-2 robot connection. Standard example address for lab equipment documentation.

static_findings_evaluation.finding: [HIGH] blocker: Weak cryptographic algorithm at references/analytical-equipment.md:387
static_findings_evaluation.reasoning: Scanner misidentified text patterns. No cryptographic code or algorithms present in documentation. False positive pattern match.
Troubleshooting instruction 'Check network connectivity (ping robot)' is legitimate lab equipment connectivity testing, not security reconnaissance.

static_findings_evaluation.finding: [CRITICAL] obfuscation: DANGEROUS COMBINATION: Code execution + Network + Credential access
static_findings_evaluation.reasoning: Scanner misidentified legitimate lab automation patterns. Network connections to Opentrons OT-2 via HTTP API are standard lab equipment integration, not credential theft or data exfiltration.

static_findings_evaluation.finding: [HIGH] obfuscation: SUSPICIOUS COMBINATION: Filesystem + Credentials + Network
static_findings_evaluation.reasoning: Documentation shows JSON file operations for saving deck layouts (serialization) and network connections to lab robots. These are standard lab automation features, not suspicious activity.

static_findings_evaluation.finding: [MEDIUM] scripts: Dynamic import() expression at references/resources.md:45
static_findings_evaluation.reasoning: Documentation shows Python import statements (from ... import ...), not dynamic import() expressions. Scanner misidentified import syntax.

static_findings_evaluation.finding: [MEDIUM] filesystem: Python file write/append at references/resources.md:291
static_findings_evaluation.reasoning: Documentation shows JSON file operations for saving/loading deck layouts. Legitimate protocol serialization, not suspicious file operations.

static_findings_evaluation.finding: [LOW] env_access: Python getenv function at references/visualization.md:431
static_findings_evaluation.reasoning: Scanner may have misidentified text patterns. No environment variable access found in examined content. Pattern match false positive.

content.user_title: Control lab automation equipment with Python
content.value_statement: PyLabRobot provides unified Python control for liquid handling robots and laboratory automation equipment. Write protocols once and run them across different hardware platforms including Hamilton, Tecan, and Opentrons robots.
actual_capabilities: Control liquid handling robots for aspirating, dispensing, and transferring liquids
Manage laboratory resources including plates, tips, troughs, and custom labware
Integrate with plate readers, scales, heater shakers, incubators, and centrifuges
Simulate protocols using ChatterboxBackend before running on physical hardware
Save and load deck layouts and resource states to JSON for reproducibility
Switch between robot backends (Hamilton STAR, Opentrons, Tecan, simulation) without rewriting protocols
limitations: Requires specific hardware backends for each robot type - not all features available on all platforms
Physical hardware access required for actual protocol execution (simulation only tests logic)
Some advanced features like Tecan EVO support are work-in-progress

use_cases.title: Automate pipetting workflows
use_cases.description: Program complex liquid transfer protocols for sample preparation, serial dilutions, and plate replication.

use_cases.title: Integrate multiple devices
use_cases.description: Coordinate liquid handlers with plate readers, scales, and environmental control equipment.

use_cases.title: Reproduce and validate protocols
use_cases.description: Save deck layouts and protocol states for consistent execution and audit trails.

prompt_templates.title: Basic pipetting
prompt_templates.prompt: Use PyLabRobot to pick up tips from tip rack position A1, aspirate 100 microliters from well A1 of a 96-well plate, and dispense into well A2.

prompt_templates.title: Plate setup
prompt_templates.prompt: Create a PyLabRobot deck with a tip rack on rail 1, source plate on rail 10, and destination plate on rail 15 using STARLetDeck.

prompt_templates.title: Multi-device workflow
prompt_templates.prompt: Set up a workflow using PyLabRobot to coordinate a Hamilton STAR liquid handler with a BMG CLARIOstar plate reader to prepare samples and read absorbance.

prompt_templates.title: Protocol testing
prompt_templates.prompt: Write a PyLabRobot protocol using ChatterboxBackend simulation to test liquid handling operations without physical hardware access.

output_examples.input: Create a deck with a tip rack and two plates, then transfer liquid from source to destination
output: Setup complete: Tip rack on rail 1, source plate on rail 10, destination plate on rail 15
Picked up tips from A1:H1 (8 tips)
Aspirated 100 ÂµL from source plate wells A1:H12
Dispensed 100 ÂµL to destination plate wells A1:H12
Tip tracking confirmed: All tips used and discarded

best_practices: Start with simulation using ChatterboxBackend to validate protocol logic before running on hardware
Enable tip tracking and volume tracking for accurate state management and debugging
Always call stop() on all devices in finally blocks to ensure proper cleanup
anti_patterns: Running protocols directly on hardware without first testing in simulation mode
Skipping error handling for hardware operations that may timeout or fail
Not saving deck layouts to JSON for reproducible protocol execution

faq.question: Which liquid handlers does PyLabRobot support?
faq.answer: PyLabRobot supports Hamilton STAR/STARlet, Opentrons OT-2, and Tecan EVO. Hamilton has full support, Opentrons uses HTTP API, Tecan is work-in-progress.

faq.question: Do I need physical hardware to test protocols?
faq.answer:: No. Use ChatterboxBackend simulation to test protocols without hardware. Works with the visualizer for real-time feedback.

faq.question: How do I save and restore deck layouts?
faq.answer: Use deck.save() and Deck.load_from_json_file() methods. Also serialize state with serialize_state() and load_state() for tip and volume tracking.

faq.question: Can I control plate readers with PyLabRobot?
faq.answer: Yes. BMG CLARIOstar plate readers are supported for absorbance, luminescence, and fluorescence measurements.

faq.question: How do I switch between different robots?
faq.answer: Change only the backend parameter (STAR, OpentronsBackend, ChatterboxBackend). Protocol code remains the same across backends.

faq.question: What is the visualizer used for?
faq.answer: The browser-based visualizer shows 3D deck state, tip presence, and liquid volumes in real-time during protocol execution or simulation.
